review_title: Teaching hospital with Magnet status makes a difference
pros: Positive, pro-nurse culture. High integrity organization. Executives make an effort to provide communication, support, and transparency. Attendings and Residents are used to the student/teacher relationship, so most are easy to talk to, happy to share their knowledge, and view mistakes as learning opportunities.
cons: Low pay for nurses compared to other locations. High turnover. Constant staffing issues. Considering the high stress environment, low pay for ancillary staff makes the positions unattractive , so RNs work most days without adequate support (HUCs, CNAs, RTs, Transport, Phlebotomy, etc). It's a smart financial decision to get a bit of experience and move on, so that's what the best team members do once they realize their worth.

review_title: Great hospital, but doesn't treat their employees well
pros: You gain a lot of experience working at a level I trauma center, so there is a lot to learn and experience. I love what I do and have only stayed because of the co-workers I work along side!
cons: Unbelievably low Morale house wide through many departments. Way under staffed in most departments that it is actually quite dangerous. Patient care gets skimmed or completely skipped because of how busy your workload is. No benefits for Part time employees. No recognition for working hard and your 2% raise doesn't ever help your huge increase in benefits every year. You have to pay to use the ER as an employee too!

pros: Great company atmosphere, staff are like family, and good cafeteria options
cons: Understanding, parking for employees is far from building

review_title: Great low effort job( most of the time)
job_title: Patient Care Attendant in Knoxville, TN
pros: If you are a student this would be a perfect job for you. As the title suggests it is low effort job so you would be able to sit down and study for hours and blow through your homework. The staff is great, alot of really chill people. Benefits are pretty good but takes a good 1/4 chunk of pay check. You get health, dental, eye, life insurance as well as 401k, flex spending( optional), differentials, and I believe they can help with school( but don't hold me to that).
cons: It can get intensely stressful at times. You mainly sit with suicide attempts/thoughts but they will put you with people who are really confused or aggressive. You get to see the worst of people at times because of head trauma, dementia or Alzheimer's, or the medicine they are on. You will get flashed ALOT and see some pretty grotesque things. If you have a weak stomach or a weak psyche do NOT work here. People will cuss you up one side and down the other for just being there. I have been bit, spit, and pissed on. The job can get really monotonous at times and you can get carried away in your thoughts.

pros: This is an amazing organization that promotes patient and family centered care. Through the Magnet designation, they provide nursing with a voice. We are supported in many ways with the most up to date technology and evidence based practice research to continue reinforcing or perfecting our skill set at the bedside. Our senior leadership is frequently reviewing ways to express their gratitude to the bedside care providers.
cons: Pay is not as great as our competitors even though benefits are amazing. For being known as the largest hospital, only Level I Taruma Center in our region, and the place for excellent treatment of the highest acuity of patients, it is surprising that hourly salary is not more competitive.

pros: Decent benefits and paid time off.
cons: The new managers over desktop don't listen to their employees suggestions to make the technology in the hospital work better.  They have zero respect for employees that have been there for a long time and are pretty much trying to push them out the door.  They have no interest in moving anyone up in the department. They would rather hire a TEK systems temp in and hire them later on than promote their staff they already have in place.

review_title: Low morale and too much overhead
pros: While I was only at UTMC for close to a year, I met a lot of great people.  Most were very stressed and under-appreciated, but they stuck it out for their patients.  UTMC has some wonderful staff members, but like mentioned in some other reviews, morale is poor.
cons: There are a few quality members of upper management, but they're outnumbered by too many incompetent, arrogant  colleagues.  I've worked for several large corporations, and UTMC has some of the craziest overhead I've ever seen.  It's like they create VP positions for every employee who's been around for a certain number of years.  There are many duplicate VP positions - cleverly named differently but still the same positions.

pros: The main pro is that as a student you get the opportunity to get a lot of experience with some very sick patients. My manager is great, and has been very understanding with my schedule with school. The equipment is the nicest around.
cons: The nurses (on my floor at least) give that "you're a student, so you need to learn" line a lot, which in reality is them not wanting to come and help turn, bath, or assist a patient.

review_title: I love the job and the people I work with, but the problems come with the pay and technical stuff.
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros: The people I work with at UT are awesome. Most of them are really compassionate and understanding and will try to help you out when you need it. The leaders on my floor are really flexible and nice. Once you work there for a little while it seems like a family.
cons: As with any family/ group of people, there are rotten eggs. The workers that skim by aren’t weeded out as they should be and they don’t get in trouble for things like they should to stop it from happening. The company values are a nice selling point, but that’s not how a lot of employees function

review_title: Level 1 trauma center in Knoxville Tennessee
pros: University of Tennessee Medical Center is a large state of the art Level One trauma center. The physicians and nursing  staff are very knowledgeable accounting for great patient outcomes.
cons: Premium parking available only to very tenured employees.  Everybody else has to park at some walking distance.  New employees park almost a mile away from the hospital.  Employees walk in the rain, snow etc.  The pay received is less than surrounding area hospitals. While the hospital has many new types of patient care related technologies, they fail to provide simple devices that promote employee protection, i.e. patient lifting equipment.

pros: They will hire you right out of school with no work experience.  I got valuable experience there, got to learn a lot.
cons: There is no chance of moving up. They have combined the monitor tech and huc positions on night shift. They will train you for other positions,  but not promote at all. The whole company's feel is that they don't want to pay. They will work you to death. A lot of nurses have a contempt for the CNA's. Pay is the lowest in the region. No matter how hard you work, it's never enough.

pros: Great teamwork and support within departments. They encourage team members to further their education and provide opportunities to take classes to further their knowledge on applications.
cons: Clinical employees are recognized and rewarded the majority of the time and they don't care to recognize the IT department whatsoever. IT department is constantly screamed at and treated poorly by most clinical staff. Upper level management is only focused towards achieving the next level of awards or recognition rather than providing non clinical staff a stable working environment. I completely understand that IT does not deal with patient care, but it would be nice to be acknowledged for the work they do.

pros: Additional perks such as employer contribution to 403b, discounted football tickets to select games, decent health insurance, and employer assistance with continuing education. Teaching hospital with lots of information resources. Magnet status hospital.
cons: Administration can seem out of touch with wants/needs of employees. Rate of pay for new hire/new grad nurses is lower than surrounding hospitals. They constitute this by saying all other perks make up for difference in pay rate. Annual raises range from 1-3% depending on performance and department manager. Cost of living raise is not a guarantee. Must sign contract saying you will get Bachelor's degree if you are an Associate degree nurse. Typical patient load for day or night shift is 6 patients.

pros: We are a team working for our patients! Working here several years, has allowed many opportunities to explore different areas within the institution! Opportunities are plentiful with hard work and dedication. It amazes me how much everyone gets involved including Senior management to ensure our patients receive the best care. I have personally encouraged many family and friends to join our work family! Opportunities for learning are endless! The excellent care provided, and the positive patient outcomes make you proud to be part of the institution!
cons: Not really any cons that would deter you from working here, and enjoying your job!

pros: I love working with most of the people here especially other fellow nurses. These nurses work hard for their patients.
cons: I am very disappointed in management. They usually never know what is going on. They are either too busy attending meetings or too busy in their office. Also, they never listen to any of the staff about suggestions and let them give their input on things. I feel like they are making decisions based on their own personal judgement not as a team. I was disappointed on how they handled certain situations.

review_title: UT has great medical care but is uninterested in making it a good environment to work for overall.
pros: I've worked at UT for over 10 years. We provide excellent medical care and have cutting edge practice compared to other local hospitals where I have worked. Nursing has a voice in decisions through Unit Councils though management has final approval, of course.
cons:
Management is willing to push employees to the max and has demonstrated lack of concern when many, many experienced employees have left due to working conditions. One manager can be quoted as saying, "Nurses are like prostitutes, there's one on every corner." This was said in front of other witnesses after I expressed concern over all the great people we were losing at the time. When this was reported to upper management no action was taken, no changes were implemented and working conditions have continued to deteriorate--and this was over a year ago. 

Also, the medical center, as a whole, is very inflexible to change. If that's the way it has always been done then, by God, that's the way we are going to do it. When all other area hospitals only require full-time nurses to work 3 twelve hour shifts a week to be considered full time and only require weekend shifts every 3-4 weeks UT still requires an every other weekend schedule. Staff with no family/no kids can probably do this easily but if one has older children and wants them to have a normal life with sports and other activities it becomes very difficult to manage not being there for them half of their life--because that is what a 7 day per 14 day work schedule requires.

Lack of equipment when needed!   At the other hospital that I work in, if we truly need more equipment to do our job well management makes it a huge priority to get it for us. This support comes from upper management and allows our department to function very effectively. I don't see this at UT at all. The normal response to needs is, "Well, we don't have the funds but we'll put it in next years' budget." I'm creative and such but I get really tired of constantly having to "make do" while still trying to give excellent care--in a Level 1 Trauma Center, by the way!!!

job_title: Bed Board RN in Knoxville, TN
pros: I enjoyed working at UT Hospital because it is a teaching hospital.  Lots of opportunities to learn different skills related to the medical field.  I enjoyed working in the ICU and learning about different procedures and using life saving equipment.
cons: The times of not having enough staff for the shift you work is very stressful and is hard to work the 12 hour shift like I did for many years.  I worked there for 25 years.

job_title: Home Health RN in Knoxville, TN
pros:
Good pay

Friendly coworkers

Up to date Tablet documentation
cons:
Anywhere from 2-5 emails daily regarding numbers and scores that we must reach and a revolving list of things we must begin doing/saying, change or discontinue. 

Patients seems to be not much more than a survey score.

review_title: Good to get foot in the door bad for long time employment
job_title: Sterile Processing Technician in Knoxville, TN
pros: Gets your foot in the door as they'll hire entry lvl and pay for your exam if you pass it.
cons: For a training hospital the training is a joke. Understaffed because pay is low and people's attitudes are poor. Chase away hard workers because there is no accountability for doing things not to standard. Honestly I'm surprised there haven't been more inquiries with infection control. No one cares about patient safety.

pros: Great teamwork, support of nurses throughout their career, magnet facility, awesome experience with the sickest of patients, continuing education support, opportunities to grow, flexible hours/shifts, ability to transfer within the facility, yearly raises, and equitable pay.
cons: Hard work, very sick patients, low wage index for this area of the USA.

job_title: Certified Nursing Aid in Knoxville, TN
pros: I was a CNA floater. If I preferred a particular floor they worked with me to stay on the floor as long as possible. Also, since I was in school they were very accommodating to my schedule.
cons: Sometimes I  would be scheduled for multiple floors at the same time as a scheduling error and get yelled at like it was my fault. It finally got worked out though.

review_title: Somewhat okay insurance benefits...but crappy everything else.
job_title: Certified Nurse Assistant in Knoxville, TN
pros: *Required five words for Pros*
cons: They don't appreciate the people that work for them as a whole. They give you "a cost of living" raise...which is a joke, because it is only $0.04 more once per year.  Standard raise is 2%,(and by 2%, I mean 1% in the end, which is only a whopping $0.10 more per hour) but they always find something negative to mention to lower your "raise" during your evaluation. I had my raise lowered because other people weren't getting along (it affected all CNA's on our unit). It had nothing to do with me whatsoever. You also don't get paid extra for working holidays and you will pretty much work every holiday. They do not offer any type of paid vacation time , paid sick, or personal days. You accrue "paid time off" and sick leave per pay period, but if you get sick, you have to use your paid time off and not your sick time. You also get written up if you are sick and can't come in more than twice a year and you have to be able to request your paid time off in advance by at least 4 months. They also split Saturdays, so you will never get overtime...ever. The equipment you have to use to do your job never works and you have to take time to call maintence over and over for them to come up and say that they fixed it, when they really didn't. If you are one of the fortunate people that is well liked by your manager you will never have consequences for abusing time off, not doing your job, or being really, really unprofessional. Don't even bother to speak up about any of this. I've seen perfectly good, hard working people get written up and even fired for doing this. The hospital itself isn't terrible, and it does do evidence based practice, which is good, but employee relations suck something awful here.

pros: Working at a teaching hospital provides the opportunity to be a part of a multi-disciplinary team. Level 1 trauma center provides care for the entire Eastern Tennessee area. Exposure to a variety of patient populations.
cons: Salary levels are below average for the area. Revolving door of upper management in the emergency department for past several years leads to instability in the department.

pros: UTMC is a great place to work.  As a Magnet organization, they value nurses! Nurses are part of the decision making process and truly have a voice.  The culture is built on teamwork, they encourage furthering education, and focus on patient and team member safety.  I am proud to work at UTMC!
cons: No cons to share...this is a great place to work!

review_title: Inadequate staffing leads to disgruntled employees
pros: Lots of resources, friendly staff
cons: Always short staffed. Doing the work of 2 or more people while being paid an embarrassing amount. Taking 15 patients on night shift has become our normal, and sometimes we have 30. It’s not safe. I feel as though I am constantly doing damage control and not actually getting to do my job and provide any patient care.

job_title: Registered Nurse, Emergency Room in Knoxville, TN
pros: -Flexible hours in the ER
cons:
- Poor pay for an experienced RN
- Poor management
- Only cared about a quick patient turn over, not quality patient care
- Unpredictable assignments, you never knew where they were going to assign you or if they were going to move you in the middle of your shift

review_title: Under the new management things have taken a bit of a downfall.
pros: Outstanding hospital, friendly co-workers. Great team of individuals, always striving to help each other but most of all our patients.
cons: Hard to almost impossible to get promoted. The only way to get a promotion is to go work at another facility.

pros:
The medical center is one large family where everyone truly cares its patients and the community. Safety and collaboration are always a priority and encouraged across disciplines. 

Great benefits and generous time off!
cons: Walking from your parking spot can be a drag in bad weather.

review_title: I didn't leave on bad terms
job_title: Emergency Department RN in Knoxville, TN
pros:
you get to meet the best people that you will EVER work with
very close-knit environment
the support and teamwork that you receive from your coworkers is unparalleled
cons: see "advice to management" section of this review

pros: Co-workers, the mission of UTMC
cons: Declining employee benefits, politics, turnover

job_title: Senior Nurse Manager in Knoxville, TN
pros: Nurses have a voice, commitment to quality

review_title: Good Step on the way up
pros: this company has very good benefits especially for families or for dependents.  Vacation pay & PTO are good as well as health insurance

job_title: Manager of Windows in Vonore, TN
pros: Great people hard working for the good of the community.  Keeping up with technology to help patient care.
cons: Too many level of management and politics involved.  IT needed more control of IT systems, without non IT people making decisions.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in Knoxville, TN
pros: I worked here for 14 years, and was pleased with the flexibility and availability of shifts for an RN.  Also, the 403b retirement benefits are great with an employer match of contributions.
cons: Like most hospitals, it struggles to keep up with the demands of increasing patient visits.

pros: Human Resources Nurse Recruiter responded to my application within 3 days of submission. Found out what I wanted most from my nursing career and I am now hired in a position that fits my needs 2 weeks later.
cons: I really don't have anything negative to say.

pros: Great employees. Nurses are great to each other and are great about teaching.
cons:
Pay sucks (but that's all of Knoxville)
Management only cares about the bottoms dollar
Always under staffed
There is a culture of "don't volunteer a mistake if you'd like to remain employed"
Management is only visible when JACHO is here
Nurses aren't happy and constantly afraid for their jobs.

cons: We are growing and that provides headaches sometimes with parking and construction challenges.

pros: Health Benefits ,paid time off , and teamwork environment, free flu shot yearly.

pros: This hospital is the top notch hospital in our area.
